10.1 Acronyms of Physics: Chapter 4







\(A =\) Action
\(E = E_{kin} + E_{pot} =\) total energy


\(t =\) time
\(r =\) dpace (distance between two points, one-dimensional length)


\(v =\) velocity
\(c =\) light speed


\(p =\) momentum
\(F =\) force


\(I =\) inertia
\(\mathcal{L} =\) Lagrangian


\(\mathcal{H} =\) Hamiltonian
\(\mathcal{K} =\) kinetic Energy


\(\mathcal{U} =\) effective potential Energy (\(\in E_{pot}\))
\(\mathcal{V} =\) potential Energy (\(\in E_{pot}\))


\(\mathcal{Z} = \frac{1}{2}\frac{L_0^2}{mr^2} =\) Centrifugal Potential
\(V = r_1 \cdot r_2 \cdot r_3 =\) Volume


\(\mathcal{k} =\) Wave Vector (“curvature”)
\(W =\) Work (done vs. received)


\(P =\) Pressure
\(L_0 =\) angular momentum


\(T =\) endogen Temperature
\(H =\) exogen Heat


\(U =\) endogen Energy (\(E_{kin} + E_{pot}\))
\(\Phi = \frac{\mathcal{V}}{q} =\) Electric Potential


\(\mathcal{A} =\) Magnetic Potential
\(b_0 =\) Boltzmann constant


\(g_0 =\) Gas constant
\(m =\) mass


\(q =\) charge
$\(n =\) amount of objectes (particles density \(n=\frac{N}{V}\)), \(n=2\) and \(f=1\)


\({\epsilon}_0 =\) electric constant
\(f = 3n \pm z =\) degrees of freedom, \(f=1\) and \(n=2\)


\({\mu}_0 =\) magnetic constant
\(\mathcal{B} =\) Magnetic Field


\(\mathcal{E} =\) Electric Field
H\(\mathcal{C} = m \cdot c_0 = \frac{\Delta H}{\Delta T}  =\) heat capacity


\(c_0 = \frac{1}{m}\frac{\Delta H}{\Delta T} =\) specific heat
\(S = b_0 \cdot \ln(\Omega) =\) Entropy (macro state)


\(l =\) Moll quantity
\(\Omega =\) micro states

title: Physics Concepts as Indicative Framework to Model Systems of Economies Ex-ante
text:
10.2 Acronyms of Economy: Chapter 8







\(T =\) Taxes
\(M =\) Import of Goods and Services from foreing symstes


\(G =\) Governent Expenses, incl. Social Insurances
\(X =\) Export of Goods and Services to foreign system


\(Y =\) Income of Economy from Turnover
\(G_A =\) Governental Subsidies


\(D_A =\) Depreciations (Reinvestments) on Assets
\(V_N =\) Net Naötional Production, Society NNP


\(N =\) Monetary Quantity
\(Q =\) Monetary Turnover Velocity


\(V_I =\) Gross Domestic Product GDP = \(\frac{Output}{Input}\), Tradevolume
\(P =\) Price niveau (Inflation adjusted Value)


\(L =\) Wages from Labor Work (Salaries, …)
\(R =\) Returns, Earnings, Gains


\(Y_A =\) Income of priv. Business Households (Companies, Services, Real Estate Rentals, Retained Profits)
\(Y_H =\) Income from priv. Capital Households (Interests, Coupons, Dividends, … of priv. Assets, Investmens, Credits, Debits, Bonds, Equity)


\(T_A=\) Tax on Capital of Corprate Compaies (Business Assets)
\(Y_G =\) Governmental Income from Assets, Services, Social Institutions/Insurances


\(Z_G =\) Interests on Governmental Debt
\(V_S =\) Gross National Produkt, Society GNP


\(I =\) Investments on Assets, incl. Storage Change
\(R_M =\) Capital Earnings and Wages from Abroad (from Foreign System)


\(R_X\) Capital Earnings and Wages to Abroad (to Foreign System)
\(W =\) Expensens, costs from human and machinary work efforts

title: PHYSECON
text:
Work (transformation)
\[\begin{split} &
W = F \cdot d = \Delta E = eV = \Delta U + \Delta C = energychange + temperaturechange
\end{split} \tag{1}\]

title: PHYSECON
text:
Wavelength (Oscillation):
\[\begin{split} &
\lambda =
\frac{h}{p} =
\frac{2\pi}{k} =
\omega \frac{\mathcal{T}}{k} =
\frac{c}{\nu} =
r \cdot cos( \frac{\pi}{2} -  \alpha ) =
2 \frac{d}{n} \sqrt{\eta^2 - sin^2(\alpha)} =
2\pi \frac{2d}{\Delta \varphi} \sqrt{\eta^2 - sin^2(\alpha)} =
2d \frac{\eta}{n} cos(\beta) =
2\pi \eta \frac{2d}{\Delta \varphi} \cos(\beta)
\stackrel{\alpha=0=\beta}{=}
2 \eta \frac{\Delta d}{\Delta n}
\end{split} \tag{1}\]
\[\begin{split} &
\Delta\lambda =
\frac{h}{m_e c}(1-cos(\varphi)) =
2 \frac{h}{m_e c} sin^2(\frac{\varphi}{2})
\end{split} \tag{2}\]
Wavefunction:
\[\begin{split} &
\Psi(x,t) =
C \cdot e^{ i(\omega t - kx) } =
C \cdot e^{ \frac{i}{\hbar}(Et - pr) }
\stackrel{Wavepacket}{=}
A(x,t) e^{i(\omega_0 t - k_0 x)} =
2 C(k_0) \frac{ sin \left[\left( t \cdot \left( \frac{d\omega}{dk} \right)_{k_0} - x \right) \cdot \Delta k \right] }{ \left( t \cdot \left( \frac{d\omega}{dk} \right)_{k_0} - x \right) } =
2 C(k_0) \frac{ sin \left[\left( \omega't - x \right) \cdot \Delta k \right] }{ \left( \omega't - x \right) } =
2 C(k_0) \Delta k \frac{sin(\xi)}{\xi}
\end{split} \tag{3}\]

title: PHYSECON
text:
Solid Angle (spacial direction)
Solid Angle (rotational measurement of spherical direction): 
\[\begin{split} &
\Omega =
\frac{A}{R^2} =
\int\limits_A \frac{\cos(\varepsilon)}{R^2} \, dA   \qquad  \in \left[ 0, 4\pi \right]
\end{split} \tag{1}\]
where \(A \equiv\) spherical Area, \(R \equiv\) spherical Radius (radial distance), and \(\varepsilon = d\vec{A} \cdot \vec{e}_n = \angle(dA,R)\) inclination angle of \(dA\) to \(R\) along the curved surface \(A\)
\[\begin{split} &
dA = \frac{R^2}{\cos(\varepsilon)} \sin(\theta) d\theta d\varphi = \frac{R^2}{\cos(\varepsilon)}d\Omega
\end{split} \tag{2}\]
where \(\varphi \equiv\) horizontal angle, \(\theta \equiv\) vertical angle
Symmetry of wave propagation from electromagnetic radiation in vacuum (Reversibility of Beam according 
\[\begin{split} &
d\Omega_g =
\frac{\mathscr{M}}{\mathscr{J}} dA_g =
\frac{dA_b}{R} \frac{\cos(\varepsilon_b)}{R} =
\frac{dA_b \cos(\varepsilon_b)}{R^2}
\end{split} \tag{3}\]
\[\begin{split} &
d\Omega_b =  
\frac{\mathscr{M}}{\mathscr{J}} dA_b =
\frac{dA_g}{R} \frac{\cos(\varepsilon_g)}{R} =  
\frac{dA_g \cos(\varepsilon_g)}{R^2}
\end{split} \tag{4}\]
\[\begin{split} &
d\Omega =
\sin(\theta) d\theta d\varphi =
\frac{dA_{\perp}}{R^2} =
\frac{\cos(\varepsilon)}{R^2}dA =
\mathscr{J} \cdot d\Omega_g = \mathscr{M} \cdot dA_g =
\mathscr{J} \cdot \mathscr{M}_b \cdot \frac{\varepsilon_b}{R^2}
\end{split} \tag{5}\]
where \(\mathscr{J} \equiv\) Flux Density, \(\mathscr{M} \equiv\) Radiant Exitance

title: PHYSECON
text:
Optical Resolution (sharpness, blur)
spectral Resolution \(\mathscr{R} = \frac{\lambda}{\Delta \lambda}\)
\[\begin{split}  &
    - Prisma with L \equiv" \text{base length} (\text{angle} \equiv \varepsilon):   \\&
     \frac{\lambda}{d \lambda} = -L \frac{d\eta}{d\lambda}    \\&
    - \text{Diffraction Lattice}:  \frac{\lambda}{\delta\lambda} = nN    \\&
    -  \text{Interferometer}: \frac{\lambda}{\Delta\lambda} = n \cdot \frac{\pi \cdot r}{1 - r^2} = nN_e    \\&
    - \text{Planparallel Plate}:  \frac{\lambda}{d\lambda} = \frac{x}{2d\tan(\beta)} \left(n - \frac{2d}{\cos(\beta)}\frac{d\eta}{d\lambda} \right)
\end{split} \tag{1}\]

objct is self-luminescent, lightwaves are incoherent and resolution is restricted: 

Tele) object far and big, min. size for resolution:
\[\begin{split} &
\Delta y_{min} =
1.22 \cdot f^{Obj} \cdot \frac{\lambda}{D}
\end{split} \tag{2}\]
where “Diameter stop” \(\equiv D\) and view angle min. for “tele” resolution (object far and big):
\[\begin{split} &
\Delta \varepsilon_{min} =
\frac{\Delta y_{min}}{f^{Obj}} =
1.22 \cdot \frac{\lambda}{D}
\end{split} \tag{3}\]
\(\Longrightarrow\) optical resolution “Tele”:
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{R}_{Tel} = \frac{1}{\Delta y_{min}} =
0.82 \cdot \frac{1}{f^{Obj}} \cdot \frac{D}{\lambda}
\end{split} \tag{4}\]
Mikro) object close and small, min. size for resolution:
\[\begin{split} &
\Delta y_g^{min} =
\frac{1.22}{2} \cdot \frac{\lambda}{\eta} \cdot \frac{1}{\sin(u_g^{max})} =
\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{\Delta s}{\eta} \cdot \frac{1}{\sin(u_g^{max})} =
0.61 \frac{\lambda}{A}
\end{split} \tag{5}\]
where aperture angle from sender (source, “Obj”) \(\equiv u_g\), opposed to view angle \(\equiv \varepsilon\) from receiver (observer, “Oku”) and “Path differecence” \(\equiv \Delta s\) and “Aperture stop” \(\equiv A = \eta \cdot \sin(u_g^{max})\)
\(\Longrightarrow\) optical resolution “Mikro endo-luminescent”:
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{R}_{Mik(endo)} = \frac{1}{y_g^{min}}
\stackrel{backlit}{=}
\frac{A}{\lambda}
\stackrel{luminescent}{\approx}
0.82 \cdot 2 \frac{A}{\lambda} =
0.82 \cdot 2 \sin(u) \frac{\eta}{\lambda}
\end{split} \tag{6}\]

objct has no self-luminousity and is illuminated externally, lightwaves interfer coherently after diffraction: 

Mikro) object close and small, min. size for resolution:
\[\begin{split} &
\Delta y \cdot \sin(u_g) = n \cdot \lambda
\qquad n \in \mathbb{N}
\end{split} \tag{7}\]
\[\begin{split} &
\Delta y_{min} = \frac{\lambda}{A} =
\frac{\lambda}{\sin(u_g)} =
\frac{\lambda}{ \frac{\lambda}{\Delta y} }
\qquad A \equiv Aperture
\end{split} \tag{8}\]
\(\Longrightarrow\) optical resolution “Mikro exo-illuminated”:
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{R}_{Mik(exo)} =
\frac{1}{\Delta y_{min}} =
\frac{A}{\lambda} =
\frac{\sin(u_g)}{\lambda}
\end{split} \tag{9}\]

title: PHYSECON
text:
Reflection and Transmission, reflection amplitude coefficients:
\[\begin{split} &
a_{r\parallel} =
\frac{ \mathscr{E}_{0,r\parallel} }{ \mathscr{E}_{0,\alpha\parallel} } =
- \frac{sin(\alpha - \beta)}{sin(\alpha + \beta)}
\end{split} \tag{1}\]
\[\begin{split} &
a_{r\perp} =
\frac{ \mathscr{E}_{0,r\perp} }{ \mathscr{E}_{0,\alpha\perp} } =
\frac{tan(\alpha - \beta)}{tan(\alpha + \beta)}
\end{split} \tag{2}\]
Reflection:
\[\begin{split} &
A_r =
\frac{P_r}{P_\alpha} =
\frac{a_{r\perp}^2 \mathscr{E}^2_{0,\alpha\perp} + a_{r\parallel}^2 \mathscr{E}^2_{0,\alpha\parallel} }{\mathscr{E}^2_{0,\alpha\perp} + \mathscr{E}^2_{0,\alpha\parallel}}
\end{split} \tag{3}\]
transmission amplitude coefficients:
\[\begin{split} &
a_{t\parallel} =
\frac{ \mathscr{E}_{0,t\parallel} }{ \mathscr{E}_{0,\alpha\parallel} } =
2 \frac{sin(\alpha)sin(\beta)}{sin(\alpha + \beta)}
\end{split} \tag{4}\]
\[\begin{split} &
a_{t\perp} =
\frac{ \mathscr{E}_{0,t\perp} }{ \mathscr{E}_{0,\alpha\perp} } =
2 \frac{sin(\alpha)sin(\beta)}{sin(\alpha + \beta)cos(\alpha - \beta)}
\end{split} \tag{5}\]
Transmission:
\[\begin{split} &
A_t =  
\frac{P_t}{P_\alpha} =
\frac{a_{t\perp}^2 \mathscr{E}^2_{0,\alpha\perp} + a_{t\parallel}^2 \mathscr{E}^2_{0,\alpha\parallel} }{\mathscr{E}^2_{0,\alpha\perp} + \mathscr{E}^2_{0,\alpha\parallel}}
\end{split} \tag{6}\]
\(A_r + A_t = 1\)
Finess (Sharpness, Linedistance, “Halbwärtsbreite”):
\[\begin{split} &
\mathcal{F} =
{\frac{4 a_r^2}{(1-a_r^2)^2}}
= \text{finess coefficient)}
\end{split} \tag{7}\]
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{F} =
\frac{\pi}{2} \sqrt{ \frac{4 a_r^2}{(1-a_r^2)^2} } =
\frac{\pi}{2} \sqrt{ \mathcal{F} }
\end{split} \tag{8}\]

title: PHYSECON
text:
Orientation of Radiation:



Radiation


\(\vartheta =\) reflection angle for redirected radiation \(A_{r\parallel}\) parallel to \(\alpha\) from matter 
\(\theta =\) diffraction angle for redirected radiation \(A_{r\perp}\) orthogonal to \(\alpha\) from matter 
\(\varpi = \beta_1 + \beta_2 =\) angle of converging body surfaces (point tip of prismic medium), spread angle of prism
\(\varsigma =\) deviation angle of redirected ray beam after refraction (transmission) and diffraction
\(u_g =\) aperture angle (acceptance) from sender source (at distance \(g\))
\(w_b =\) inclination angle at observer receiver (at distance \(b\))
\(\varepsilon =\) visual angle from observer/receiver (of eye)

title: PHYSECON
text:
Thermal Radiation:
Spectral Reflection: \[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{R}(\lambda) =
\frac{d^3\Phi_{\lambda,r}}{d^3\Phi_{\lambda,e}}
\end{split} \tag{1}\]
Spectral Transmission: \[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{T}(\lambda) =
\frac{d^3\Phi_{\lambda,t}}{d^3\Phi_{\lambda,e}}
\end{split} \tag{2}\]
Spectral Absorbtion: \[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{A}(\lambda) =
\frac{d^3\Phi_{\lambda,a}}{d^3\Phi_{\lambda,e}}
\end{split} \tag{3}\]
Spectral Emission: \[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{E}(\lambda) =
\frac{\mathscr{L}(\lambda)}{\mathscr{L}(\lambda,B)}
\end{split} \tag{4}\]
\(\mathscr{R}(\lambda) + \mathscr{T}(\lambda) + \mathscr{A}(\lambda) = 1\)
Black Body “B”: \[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{A}(\lambda,T) = \mathscr{E}(\lambda,T) = 1,\
\mathscr{R}(\lambda,T) = 0,\
\mathscr{T}(\lambda,T) = 0
\end{split} \tag{5}\]
\(\Rightarrow\) Heat Radiation (Black Body): 
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{L}_{B} =
\frac{c}{4\pi} \langle w_{EM} \rangle =
\frac{c}{4\pi} w_B
\end{split} \tag{6}\]
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{L}_{\lambda,B}(\lambda,T) =
\frac{\mathscr{L}_{\lambda}(\lambda,T)}{\mathscr{A}_{\lambda}(\lambda,T)}
\stackrel{continuum}{=}
\frac{2c}{\lambda^4}kT
\stackrel{quantum}{=}
\frac{2hc^2}{\lambda^5}  \frac{1}{e^{\frac{hc}{\lambda kT}}-1} =
const.
\end{split} \tag{7}\]
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{L}_{\nu,B}(\nu,T)
\stackrel{quantum}{=}
\frac{2h\nu^3}{c^2}  \frac{1}{e^{\frac{hc}{kT}}-1}
\end{split} \tag{8}\]
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{L}_{\lambda,B}(\lambda_x,T_x) =
\left( \frac{T_x}{T} \right)^5 \cdot \mathscr{L}_{\lambda,B}(\lambda,T)
\end{split} \tag{9}\]
\(T_x > T \Rightarrow \lambda_x < \lambda\)
\[\begin{split} &
\lambda_{max} \cdot T =
\frac{h \cdot c}{5k} \frac{1}{1 - e^{-\lambda_{max} \cdot T}} =
b = 2.897773 \cdot 10^{-3} m \cdot K
\end{split} \tag{10}\]
Heat Radiation Transfer (sent from source \(g\) to receiver \(b\) with areas \(\mathscr{A}\)):

\[\begin{split} &
d^2\Phi
\stackrel{vacuum}{=}
\mathscr{L} \frac{dA_g \cos(\varepsilon_g)}{R} \frac{dA_b \cos(\varepsilon_b)}{R} =
\frac{\mathscr{L}}{R^2} \cdot dA_g \cos(\varepsilon_g) \cdot dA_b \cos(\varepsilon_b) =
\mathscr{L} \cos(\varepsilon_b) dA_b d\Omega_b
\end{split} \tag{11}\]
Heat Radiation Return, Reflection Absorbtion (Feedback absorbed “\(a\)” at sender \(g\) received “\(e\)” at receiver \(b\), with areas \(\mathscr{A}\) at wavelength \(\lambda\) ):  
\[\begin{split} &
d^3\Phi_{\lambda,a,b}
\stackrel{vacuum}{=}
\mathscr{A}_b \cdot d^3\Phi_{\lambda,e,b} =
\mathscr{A}_b \cdot \mathscr{L}_{\lambda} \cos(\varepsilon_b) d\mathscr{A}_b d\Omega_b d\lambda =
\mathscr{L}_{\lambda,b} \cos(\varepsilon_g) d\mathscr{A}_g d\Omega_g d\lambda =
d^3\Phi_{\lambda,b}
\end{split} \tag{12}\]

Energy Density w and Pressure \(P\), Temperature \(T\), Volume \(V\), inner Energy \(U\), Entropy density \(s\), Radiance 
\(\mathscr{L}_B\):
\[\begin{split} &
w_B =
\frac{\mathscr{L}_B}{c} \int\limits_0^{4\pi} d\Omega =
\frac{4\pi}{c} \cdot \mathscr{L}_B =
\frac{4}{c} \cdot \mathscr{M}_B =
2 \cdot 2\pi \cdot \frac{\mathscr{L}_B}{c}
\stackrel{oriented}{=}
P_{EM}
\stackrel{unoriented}{=}
3 w_{EM} =
3 \left( \varepsilon_0 \varepsilon_r \mathscr{E}^2 \right) =
3 P_B =
3 \left( - \frac{dW}{dV} \right)_B =
3 \left( - \frac{d(F \cdot x)}{dV} \right)_B =
3 \left( - \frac{m}{V} \cdot x \cdot \ddot{x} \right)_B =
T \frac{\partial P}{\partial T} - P =
\frac{\partial U}{\partial V} =
aT^4 =
\frac{3}{4} T \cdot s_B
\end{split} \tag{13}\]
\[\begin{split} &
w_{\lambda,B}
\stackrel{continuum}{=}
- \frac{dn}{d\lambda} \overline{W} = \frac{8\pi}{\lambda^4}kT
\stackrel{quantum}{=}
\frac{8\pi hc}{\lambda^5} \frac{1}{e^{\frac{hc}{kT}}-1} =
8\pi h \nu \frac{1}{\lambda^4} \frac{1}{e^{\frac{hc}{kT}}-1}
\end{split} \tag{14}\]
\[\begin{split} &
w_{\nu,B}
\stackrel{continuum}{=}
\frac{dn}{d\nu} \overline{W} = \frac{8\pi\nu^2}{c^3}kT
\stackrel{quantum}{=}
\frac{8\pi h\nu^3}{c^3} \frac{1}{e^{\frac{hc}{kT}}-1} =
8\pi h \left(\frac{1}{\lambda}\right)^3 \frac{1}{e^{\frac{hc}{kT}}-1}
\end{split} \tag{15}\]

where Radiant Exitance (Emittance)  \(\mathscr{M}_B = \frac{d\Phi}{dA_g} = \sigma T^4\) and proportionality constants:
\(a = \frac{2^3}{3\cdot5} \frac{\pi^5 k^4}{h^3 c^3} = 7.5657 \cdot 10^{-16}Jm^{-3}K^{-4}\) (\(a\) = constant from integration)
\(\sigma = \frac{1}{4} \cdot a \cdot c = \frac{2}{3\cdot5} \frac{\pi^5 k^4}{h^3 c^3}  = 5.6704 \cdot 10^{-8}Wm^{-2}K^{-4}\) (\(c\) = light speed)
\[\begin{split} &
\frac{d}{d\Omega} P_{EM}
\stackrel{oriented}{=}
\frac{d}{d\Omega} w_B =
\frac{\mathscr{L}_B}{c}
\end{split} \tag{16}\]
Blackbody Entropy Density \(s_B = \frac{4}{3} aT^4\)
Blackbody Entropy \(S_B = \frac{4}{3} aVT^3\)
Blackbody Inner Energy \(U_B = aVT^4\)
Blackbody Pressure \(P_B = \frac{1}{3} aT^4 \stackrel{unoriented}{=} \frac{1}{3} w_B\)

title: PHYSECON
text:

\[\begin{split} &
c =

v_{gr}

where:

title: PHYSECON
text:
Intensity (density, concentration)
Irradiance, Intensity is impact at receiver (observer in distance b):
\(\mathscr{I} \equiv\) Irradiation, Intensity, “straight impact” at receiver (observer surface orthogonal to ray beam, \(\mathscr{A}_b \perp R\)) 
\(\Phi \equiv\) Power (Flux) = \(\frac{W}{t} = \frac{F \cdot x}{t} = \frac{dE}{dt} = mva = pa\)
\(\mathscr{S} \equiv\) Poynting-Vector, Radiation 
\(\mathscr{A}_b \equiv\) Area surface at observer (receiver)
\(\mathscr{A}_g \equiv\) Area surface at source (sender)
\(\Omega_g \equiv\) Solid Angle at source (sender) 
\(\Omega_b \equiv\) Solid Angle at observer (receiver)
\(\mathscr{J} \equiv\) Flux Density (Radiant Intensity), “angular emission” at source (sender) 
\(\mathscr{L} \equiv\) Radiance 
\(R \equiv\) Distance, ray beam length
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{I} =
\mathscr{I}_{\alpha} =
\langle w_{EM} \rangle \cdot c =
\langle w_{EM} \cdot c_{ph} \rangle =
\frac{1}{2} \frac{c}{\eta} \epsilon \mathscr{E}_0^2 =
\frac{1}{2} c_{ph} \epsilon_0 \mathscr{E}_0^2 =
\frac{1}{\mu_0} | \mathscr{E} \times \mathscr{B} | =
\langle | \mathscr{E} \times \mathscr{B} | \rangle =
\langle | \mathscr{S} | \rangle =  
\langle \Phi \rangle =  
\frac{d\Phi}{d\mathscr{A}_b} =
\frac{d\Phi}{d\Omega_g} \frac{\cos(\varepsilon_b)}{R^2} =
\mathscr{J} \frac{\cos(\varepsilon_b)}{R^2}
\stackrel{\mathscr{A}_b \perp \mathscr{S}, \varepsilon_b = 0}{=}
\frac{\mathscr{J}}{R^2}
\stackrel{\Omega_b=small, \mathscr{S}=const.}{=}
\int\limits_{\mathscr{A}_g} \mathscr{L} \frac{\cos(\varepsilon_g)}{R^2} d\mathscr{A}_g =
\int\limits_{\Omega_b} \mathscr{L} d\Omega_g =
4\pi \cdot \mathscr{L}_B
\end{split} \tag{1}\] 
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{I}_0
\stackrel{\mu_{r}=1}{=}
c \epsilon_{0} \left( \frac{\mathscr{E(\vartheta)}}{e^{ t (\omega t - kr) }}  \frac{sin(\frac{1}{2} \Delta \varphi )}{sin(\frac{N}{2} \Delta \varphi) }   \right )^2 =
\mathscr{I}_{A_r} + \mathscr{I}_{A_t} =
\mathscr{I}_{\vartheta} + \mathscr{I}_{\beta} =
\mathscr{I}_{A_t,max} =
\mathscr{I}_{\beta_t,max} =
\mathscr{E}_0^2
\end{split} \tag{2}\]
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{I}_{max}
\stackrel{\mu_{r}=1}{=}
\mathscr{I}_{\alpha=0=\beta} =
\mathscr{I}(0) =
N^2 \mathscr{I}_{0}
\stackrel{\mu_{r}=1}{=}
\left( N \mathscr{E}_0 \right)^2
\end{split} \tag{3}\]
Transmitted Intensity (Airy-Function) in refraction:
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{I}_{\beta_t} = \mathscr{I}_{A_t} =
\frac{1}{1 + \frac{4 a_r^2}{(1-a_r^2)^2} sin^2(\frac{\Delta\varphi}{2}) } =
\frac{1}{ 1 + \mathcal{F} \cdot sin^2(\frac{\Delta\varphi}{2}) }
\end{split} \tag{4}\]
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{I}_{A_t}(\Delta\varphi) =
\mathscr{E}^*\mathscr{E} =
\mathscr{E}_{0}^2 \frac{ \left( 1 - \left( \frac{\mathscr{E}_{0,\vartheta}}{\mathscr{E}_{0,\alpha}} \right)^2 \right)^2 }{ \left( 1 - \left( \frac{\mathscr{E}_{0,\vartheta}}{\mathscr{E}_{0,\alpha}} \right)^2 \right)^2 } \frac{1}{1+\frac{ 4 \left( \frac{\mathscr{E}_{0,\vartheta}}{\mathscr{E}_{0,\alpha}} \right)^2 }{  \left( 1 - \left( \frac{\mathscr{E}_{0,\vartheta}}{\mathscr{E}_{0,\alpha}} \right)^2 \right)^2 } \sin^2(\frac{\Delta\varphi}{2}) } =
\mathscr{E}_{0}^2 \frac{ \left( 1 - a_r^2 \right)^2 }{ \left( 1 - a_r^2 \right)^2 } \frac{1}{1+\frac{ 4a_r^2 }{  \left( 1 - a_r^2 \right)^2 } \sin^2(\frac{\Delta\varphi}{2}) } =
\mathscr{E}_0^2 \mathscr{I}_{A_t} =
\mathscr{I}_{max} \mathscr{I}_{A_t}
\end{split} \tag{5}\]
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{I}_{\beta_t,min} =
\mathscr{I}_{A_t,min} =
\mathscr{I}_{A_t,max} \cdot \frac{1}{1 + {\frac{4 a_r^2}{(1-a_r^2)^2}} } =
\mathscr{I}_{\beta_t,max} \cdot \frac{1}{1 + \mathcal{F}} =
\frac{ \mathscr{E}_0^2}{1 + \mathcal{F} }
\end{split} \tag{6}\]
Absorbed Intensitiy:
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{I} =
\mathscr{I}_{\beta_a} =
\mathscr{I}_0 e^{-al}
\stackrel{\mu_r = 1}{=}
\frac{\mathscr{E}_0^2}{e^{al}}  
\qquad  a = \textnormal{absorbtion coefficient}
\qquad  l = \textnormal{direction}
\end{split} \tag{7}\]
Reflected Intensity:
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{I}_{\vartheta}
\stackrel{\mu_{r}=1}{=}
c \epsilon_0 \langle \mathscr{E(\vartheta)}^2 \rangle =
\mathscr{I}_0 \frac{sin^2 \left (\frac{N}{2} \Delta \varphi \right)}{sin^2 \left( \frac{1}{2} \Delta \varphi \right)} =
\mathscr{I}_0 \frac{sin^2 \left( N \pi \frac{d}{\lambda} sin(\vartheta) \right) }{sin^2 \left( \pi \frac{d}{\lambda} sin(\vartheta) \right) }
\end{split} \tag{8}\]
Difracted Intensity:
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{I}_{\theta}
\stackrel{\mu_{r}=1}{=}
c \epsilon_0 \langle \mathscr{E}^2 \rangle =
\underbrace{\mathscr{I}_0}_{Max.}
\underbrace{ \left( \frac{sin(\beta)}{\beta} \right)^2 }_{Modulation}
\underbrace{ \left( \frac{sin(N \alpha)}{sin(\alpha)} \right)^2 }_{Variation}
\end{split} \tag{9}\]
\(\beta = k \frac{b}{2}sin(\theta)   \qquad  \alpha = k \frac{a}{2}sin(\theta)\)
\(a = \textnormal{particle distance} \qquad  b = \textnormal{particle size}\)
Hypothesis:
\(\left( \frac{\mathscr{J}}{R} \right)^2 = \mathscr{J} \cdot \mathscr{I}\)
\(\Rightarrow\) ray length (reach)
\(R = \sqrt{ \frac{\mathscr{J}}{\mathscr{I}} }\)

title: PHYSECON
text:
Conjecture of ?@eq-moneyquant and ?@eq-workthermal
How consistently map economic measures to the quantities of nature to model the economical system?
Input: \[\begin{split} &
Input = f_0(Resouces, Labor, Capital) \text{ = Work = } \Delta\text{Energy} = p \cdot v
\end{split} \tag{1}\]
Output: \[\begin{split} &
Output \text{ = Goods + Services = Production = } \Delta\text{State} = V_I
\end{split} \tag{2}\]
Productivity: \[\begin{split} &
Productivity = \frac{Output}{Input} = \frac{\Delta State}{\Delta Energy} = \frac{Production}{Work} = \frac{V_I}{pv}
\end{split} \tag{3}\]
see description of “movement” ?@eq-movement

As a first approach, considering the geometrical perspective of the concept of “work” (?@eq-workgeom), applied to economical measurements, so to satisfy the following system:
\(f_A(Assets) = f_B(Liabilities + Gain)\) = “momentum” \(p\) from initial state \(r_0\) to new state \(r_1\), where the change of state is \(r = r_1 - r_0\)
Matter substance, object movement/change: \[\begin{split} &
A = f_A = F \cdot t = p
\end{split} \tag{4}\]
Space of movement, maneuverability: \[\begin{split} &
B + R = f_B = m \cdot v = p
\end{split} \tag{5}\]
Work input (efforts, costs) through labor force, machines and infrastructure applied, and materials consumed for production: \[\begin{split} &
W = f_0 = F \cdot r = m \cdot \frac{v}{t} \cdot r = p \cdot v
\end{split} \tag{6}\]
Energy transfer, energy change, profit or loss: \[\begin{split} &
Y = \Delta E = \frac{1}{2} pv + \mathcal{U}
\end{split} \tag{7}\]
Production value inflation adjusted: \[\begin{split} &
P \cdot V_I = \sum Y_{adjust} = \sum (W + R)_{adjust} = \Delta U - \Delta H = Q \cdot N
\end{split} \tag{8}\]
see ?@eq-workthemostat and ?@eq-workgeom
Thus, to be determined are \(v\) (economy velocity) and \(p\) (financial structure). Eventually, determine \(r\) = “state change through trajectory” (substance change to the new assets structure) by given \(v\) = “velocity of movement” (Business speed = monetary value, price with inflation), or determine \(v\) by given \(r\). The individual positions \(\{ i,j,l,m \}\) of Liabilities \(\{ B_i + R_j \}_k\), Assets \(\{ A_m \}_k\), and Expenses \(\{ W_l \}_k\) shall be grouped in sets \(\{ k \}\), so to satisfy \(f_k(i,j) = f_k(m) = f_k(l) = \{ pv \}_k\).
The constraints shall be modelled with the Lagrangian. Hence, “Work” shall be derived from the Hamiltonian which leads to the identification of the “movement” (= change, transformation) of the trajectory (= path to new state) with \(\dot r = v\) and \(\dot p = F\).
Experiment design: \(p\) and \(v\) are modelled ex-ante with means of CONSTRAINTS from contractual agreement and from given juristic legislation, in such a way that physics laws are satisfied. Decisions making occure within this ex-ante frame.

spherical waves of Electric Field from idealized point charge (linear coherent):

\end{split} \tag{3}\]
Reflected Electric Field:
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{E(\vartheta)} =

a \cdot e^{ i (\omega t - kR) } \frac{sin(\frac{N}{2}\Delta\varphi)}{sin(\frac{1}{2}\Delta\varphi)} =

\[\begin{split} &

a \cdot e^{ i (\omega t - kR) } \frac{sin(\frac{N}{2}\Delta\varphi)}{sin(\frac{1}{2}\Delta\varphi)} =
a \cdot cos(\omega t - kR) \frac{sin(\frac{N}{2}\Delta\varphi)}{sin(\frac{1}{2}\Delta\varphi)} =
a \cdot cos(\omega t - kR) \frac{sin(\frac{N}{2}2\alpha)}{sin(\frac{1}{2}2\alpha)}
\stackrel{linear-coherent}{=}
A_L \frac{D}{R} \frac{sin(\beta)}{\beta} \cdot cos(\omega t - kR) \frac{sin(\frac{N}{2} k \cdot A_L \frac{D}{R} \frac{sin(\beta)}{\beta} \cdot sin(\theta) )}{ sin(\frac{1}{2} k \cdot A_L \frac{D}{R} \frac{sin(\beta)}{\beta} \cdot sin(\theta) } =
A_L \frac{D}{R} \frac{sin( \frac{1}{2}bk )}{ \frac{1}{2}bk } \cdot cos(\omega t - kR) \frac{sin(\frac{N}{2} k \cdot A_L \frac{D}{R} \frac{sin( \frac{1}{2}bk )}{ \frac{1}{2}bk } \cdot sin(\theta) )}{ sin(\frac{1}{2} k \cdot A_L \frac{D}{R} \frac{sin( \frac{1}{2}bk )}{ \frac{1}{2}bk } \cdot sin(\theta) }
\end{split} \tag{5}\]
where:
\(A_L = \frac{1}{D} \lim\limits_{N \rightarrow \infty}  \lim\limits_{A_0 \rightarrow 0} (N \cdot A_0)\)
\(A_0 =\) intrinsic Eigen-Amplitude of charge (“Quellstärke”) emitting radiation due to its movement (vibration)

\(R = r_{N/2} = r_1 - \frac{N-1}{2}\Delta s\) = average ray length

title: PHYSECON
text:
Society’s living requires:

“Resources” are processed to create goods to be consumed
“Labor” is used to process goods and services
“Capital” intermediates value between goods and services

Society organizes in groups of households:

natural households
juristic corporations
governmental institutions

Households cooperate though exchange (trade) of goods and services between “Demand” and “Supply” using monetary valuation:

Goods Market Production, Inventory, Trade \(\rightarrow\) “Price” for value of production
Labor Market Employment, Demographic Structure, Work Capabilities \(\rightarrow\) “Wage” for value of labor
Capital Market Savings, Investments, Exchange \(\rightarrow\) “Interest” for value of capital


acronyms see ?@sec-acroeconom


Supply is provided by the income \(Y\):
\[\begin{split} &
Y = L  + Y_H + Y_A + T_A + Y_G - Z_G
\end{split} \tag{1}\]
\[\begin{split} &
Y = C + S + T + M - X
\end{split} \tag{2}\]
Demand is satisfied by the production \(V_I\):
\[\begin{split} &
V_I = C + I + G + X - M
\end{split} \tag{3}\]
Equilibrium:
\[\begin{split} &
Y = V_I       \\&
L - C = S = I        \\&
C + S = L        \\&
C + I = R
\end{split} \tag{4}\]
Domestic Production & International Trade:
\[\begin{split} &
V_S = Y + T - G_A + D_A
\end{split} \tag{5}\]
\[\begin{split} &
V_N = V_S - D_A
\end{split} \tag{6}\]
\[\begin{split} &
V_I = V_S - R_M + R_X
\end{split} \tag{7}\]
Monetary Value of Production:
\[\begin{split} &
P \cdot V_I = Q \cdot N
\end{split} \tag{8}\]
Macro Productivity: \[\begin{split} &
Productivity = \frac{Output}{Input} = \frac{V_I}{Y}
\end{split} \tag{9}\]


We track production at microeconomic level through (acronyms see ?@sec-acroeconom):
\(A =\) Assets represent “Property Capital” which consist of “Current Capital” and “Structural Capital”. Those investments are required for the production processes.
\(B =\) Liabilities represent “Financial Capital” which consist of “Exogen Funds” and “Endogen Funds”. Later includes “Equity Capital” and “Retained Gains”. Those funds do finance Assets.
\(W =\) Expenses represent “Work Efforts” to “Supply Production” with use of Assets.
\(Y =\) Income represents “Received Earnings” achieved with production to “Satisfy Demand”. Parts of the gains will be retained to finance Assets.
\(R =\) Gain, Profit or Loss from executed work (resultant value from input efforts) is represented by \(R = Y - W\)
The “transfer of energy” between all subsystems is mapped in balancing out theirs capital (usage of capital for production though possessed assets): \(A = B + R\)
Micro Productivity: \[\begin{split} &
Productivity = \frac{Output}{Input} = \frac{Y}{W}
\end{split} \tag{10}\]

title: PHYSECON

title: PHYSECON
text:
Constraints:

initial state, starting conditions
acting boundary conditions (to move within): e.g. demography, economical and political stability, labor force, education and know-how, health and technological level
access to limited resources: e.g. chemical elements, minerals, fuels, commodities, trade and transportations, etc.
contractual agreements and covenants, legal assurance
juristic law framework

Modelling movement (change of state) under constraints:

Movement ist charecterized by change of energy, Lagrangian \(\mathcal{L} \neq 0\): \[\begin{split} &
\mathcal{L} = \mathcal{K} - \mathcal{U}
\qquad
\frac{\partial \mathcal{L}}{\partial r} = F
\qquad
\frac{\partial \mathcal{L}}{\partial v} = p
\end{split} \tag{1}\]
Movement happens within constraints of forces. Constrains are observable, whereas forces might be unknown. Therefore, \(r\) can be determined from \(\mathcal{L}\) (Energy and Work) of the system at rest \(F=0\), instead than from “searching” all acting forces \(F_i\). In general, unknow forces at motion are defined by solving the Eigenvalueproblem. Solving for \(\mathcal{L}\) at equilibirium: \[\begin{split} &
F_{total} = \hat{F_i} + \tilde{F_i} = \hat{F_i} + \sum_{k=1}^{s_d} \lambda_k a_{ki} = \frac{d}{dt} \left( \frac{\partial \mathcal{L}}{\partial v_i} \right) - \frac{\partial \mathcal{L}}{\partial r_i}
= \begin{cases}
= 0    : \text{ Equilibrium} \\
\neq 0 : \text{ Movement}
  \end{cases}
\end{split} \tag{2}\]
and at same time solving for constraining conditions that hold the system at rest (equilibrium): \[\begin{split} &
\sum_{l=1}^f a_{kl} v_l + b_k = 0
\end{split} \tag{3}\]
Rest is characterized by unchanged energy, Hamiltonian \(\mathcal{H} = E_{kin} + E_{pot} = const.\). There is movement from state of rest if the new \(\mathcal{H} \neq 0\) differs from the initial one. Using the found solution for the Lagrangian \(\mathcal{L}\) containing the constraints, the Hamiltonian for the energy is deduced: \[\begin{split} &
\mathcal{H} = \sum_i p_i v_i - \mathcal{L} = pv - \mathcal{L}  = Fr - \mathcal{L} = W - \mathcal{L}  = (\Delta E - \Delta H) - \mathcal{L}
\end{split} \tag{4}\]
Change of state/position is characterized by movement. Eventually, by solving the new system of differential equations, from the found solution of the energy \(\mathcal{H}\), the set \({r,v,p}\) which describe the movement (and thus the change of state), is deduced: \[\begin{split} &
\dot r_i = v_i = \frac{\partial\mathcal{H}}{\partial p_i}   \qquad
\dot p_i = F_i = - \frac{\partial\mathcal{H}}{\partial r_i}
\end{split} \tag{5}\]

see description of “work” ?@eq-workgeom
where:
\(s_d =\) constraints   \(i = 1,...,f =\) dedrees of freedom   \(k = 1,...,s_d =\) constraints
\(\hat{F_i} =\) known constraining forces   \(\tilde{F_i} = \sum_{k=1}^{s_d} \lambda_k a_{ki} =\) unknown constraining forces
\(\lambda_k(t) =\) Eigenvalues for transformation of reference system
\(a_{ki} =\) Eigenvectors of transformation matrix
\(\lambda_k \cdot \vec r_i = \lambda_k \cdot \left[ a_{ki} \right]_{matrix}\)

title: PHYSECON
text:
Nature strives through Physics to behave economical by using its resources in an austere way: Principle of Least Action.
Economy - not pre-given by natural laws - is constructed as social set of co-living rules to allocate, distribute and share (natural and non-natural) resources. Ex-ante modelling economic systems by rules (contractual, legislative, judicative, executive).
The state (situation, position) of the Economy can be described by e.g. Assets, Liabilities, Expenses, Incomes, Profitability, Productivity, etc.. The Economy changes through time from a state \(r_0=\) “start” to a state \(r_1=\) “end”. For the state to change, work is applied by processing limited resources (e.g. access to raw materials and availability of intermediate goods), constrained capital (e.g. financial funds, interest rates, and inflation), as well as labor capacity (e.g machines and human force).
How can a trajectory \(r = r_1 - r_0\) between two states be modelled by work \(W\), which is applied for the change of the state to occure: searching the condition by defing target state through “path of chage” \(=r\)?
\[\begin{split} &
r = f(x_i) = \int A = \int \int W = \int \int (\mathcal{L} + \mathcal{H}) = \int \int (\Delta E - \Delta H)
\end{split} \tag{1}\]

\[\begin{split} &
\varsigma =
\alpha + arcsin \left[ sin(\varpi) \sqrt{\eta^2-sin^2(\alpha)} - cos(\varpi)sin(\alpha) \right] - \varpi =
\alpha + \alpha_2 - \varpi
\end{split} \tag{3}\]
where \(\varpi = \beta + \beta_2 = const.\)
Minimal aberration (minimal projection error):
\(\varsigma = \varsigma_{min} \Longleftrightarrow\)
\[\begin{split} &
\varsigma_{min} \Longleftrightarrow \\
\frac{d}{d\alpha} \varsigma = 0
\ \wedge \\
\varsigma_{min} =
2\alpha - \varpi =
2(\alpha - \beta)
\end{split} \tag{4}\]
Thermal Radiation:
Spectral Reflection: \[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{R}(\lambda) =
\frac{d^3\Phi_{\lambda,r}}{d^3\Phi_{\lambda,e}}
\end{split} \tag{5}\]
Spectral Transmission: \[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{T}(\lambda) =
\frac{d^3\Phi_{\lambda,t}}{d^3\Phi_{\lambda,e}}
\end{split} \tag{6}\]
Spectral Absorbtion: \[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{A}(\lambda) =
\frac{d^3\Phi_{\lambda,a}}{d^3\Phi_{\lambda,e}}
\end{split} \tag{7}\]
Spectral Emission: \[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{E}(\lambda) =
\frac{\mathscr{L}(\lambda)}{\mathscr{L}(\lambda,B)}
\end{split} \tag{8}\]
\(\mathscr{R}(\lambda) + \mathscr{T}(\lambda) + \mathscr{A}(\lambda) = 1\)
Black Body “B”: \[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{A}(\lambda,T) = \mathscr{E}(\lambda,T) = 1,\
\mathscr{R}(\lambda,T) = 0,\
\mathscr{T}(\lambda,T) = 0
\end{split} \tag{9}\]
\(\Rightarrow\) Heat Radiation (Black Body): 
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{L}_{B} =
\frac{c}{4\pi} \langle w_{EM} \rangle =
\frac{c}{4\pi} w_B
\end{split} \tag{10}\]
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{L}_{\lambda,B}(\lambda,T) =
\frac{\mathscr{L}_{\lambda}(\lambda,T)}{\mathscr{A}_{\lambda}(\lambda,T)}
\stackrel{continuum}{=}
\frac{2c}{\lambda^4}kT
\stackrel{quantum}{=}
\frac{2hc^2}{\lambda^5}  \frac{1}{e^{\frac{hc}{\lambda kT}}-1} =
const.
\end{split} \tag{11}\]
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{L}_{\nu,B}(\nu,T)
\stackrel{quantum}{=}
\frac{2h\nu^3}{c^2}  \frac{1}{e^{\frac{hc}{kT}}-1}
\end{split} \tag{12}\]
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{L}_{\lambda,B}(\lambda_x,T_x) =
\left( \frac{T_x}{T} \right)^5 \cdot \mathscr{L}_{\lambda,B}(\lambda,T)
\end{split} \tag{13}\]
\(T_x > T \Rightarrow \lambda_x < \lambda\)
\[\begin{split} &
\lambda_{max} \cdot T =
\frac{h \cdot c}{5k} \frac{1}{1 - e^{-\lambda_{max} \cdot T}} =
b = 2.897773 \cdot 10^{-3} m \cdot K
\end{split} \tag{14}\]
Heat Radiation Transfer (sent from source \(g\) to receiver \(b\) with areas \(\mathscr{A}\)):

\[\begin{split} &
d^2\Phi
\stackrel{vacuum}{=}
\mathscr{L} \frac{dA_g \cos(\varepsilon_g)}{R} \frac{dA_b \cos(\varepsilon_b)}{R} =
\frac{\mathscr{L}}{R^2} \cdot dA_g \cos(\varepsilon_g) \cdot dA_b \cos(\varepsilon_b) =
\mathscr{L} \cos(\varepsilon_b) dA_b d\Omega_b
\end{split} \tag{15}\]
Heat Radiation Return, Reflection Absorbtion (Feedback absorbed “\(a\)” at sender \(g\) received “\(e\)” at receiver \(b\), with areas \(\mathscr{A}\) at wavelength \(\lambda\) ):  
\[\begin{split} &
d^3\Phi_{\lambda,a,b}
\stackrel{vacuum}{=}
\mathscr{A}_b \cdot d^3\Phi_{\lambda,e,b} =
\mathscr{A}_b \cdot \mathscr{L}_{\lambda} \cos(\varepsilon_b) d\mathscr{A}_b d\Omega_b d\lambda =
\mathscr{L}_{\lambda,b} \cos(\varepsilon_g) d\mathscr{A}_g d\Omega_g d\lambda =
d^3\Phi_{\lambda,b}
\end{split} \tag{16}\]

Energy Density w and Pressure \(P\), Temperature \(T\), Volume \(V\), inner Energy \(U\), Entropy density \(s\), Radiance 
\(\mathscr{L}_B\):
\[\begin{split} &
w_B =
\frac{\mathscr{L}_B}{c} \int\limits_0^{4\pi} d\Omega =
\frac{4\pi}{c} \cdot \mathscr{L}_B =
\frac{4}{c} \cdot \mathscr{M}_B =
2 \cdot 2\pi \cdot \frac{\mathscr{L}_B}{c}
\stackrel{oriented}{=}
P_{EM}
\stackrel{unoriented}{=}
3 w_{EM} =
3 \left( \varepsilon_0 \varepsilon_r \mathscr{E}^2 \right) =
3 P_B =
3 \left( - \frac{dW}{dV} \right)_B =
3 \left( - \frac{d(F \cdot x)}{dV} \right)_B =
3 \left( - \frac{m}{V} \cdot x \cdot \ddot{x} \right)_B =
T \frac{\partial P}{\partial T} - P =
\frac{\partial U}{\partial V} =
aT^4 =
\frac{3}{4} T \cdot s_B
\end{split} \tag{17}\]
\[\begin{split} &
w_{\lambda,B}
\stackrel{continuum}{=}
- \frac{dn}{d\lambda} \overline{W} = \frac{8\pi}{\lambda^4}kT
\stackrel{quantum}{=}
\frac{8\pi hc}{\lambda^5} \frac{1}{e^{\frac{hc}{kT}}-1} =
8\pi h \nu \frac{1}{\lambda^4} \frac{1}{e^{\frac{hc}{kT}}-1}
\end{split} \tag{18}\]
\[\begin{split} &
w_{\nu,B}
\stackrel{continuum}{=}
\frac{dn}{d\nu} \overline{W} = \frac{8\pi\nu^2}{c^3}kT
\stackrel{quantum}{=}
\frac{8\pi h\nu^3}{c^3} \frac{1}{e^{\frac{hc}{kT}}-1} =
8\pi h \left(\frac{1}{\lambda}\right)^3 \frac{1}{e^{\frac{hc}{kT}}-1}
\end{split} \tag{19}\]

where Radiant Exitance (Emittance)  \(\mathscr{M}_B = \frac{d\Phi}{dA_g} = \sigma T^4\) and proportionality constants:
\(a = \frac{2^3}{3\cdot5} \frac{\pi^5 k^4}{h^3 c^3} = 7.5657 \cdot 10^{-16}Jm^{-3}K^{-4}\) (\(a\) = constant from integration)
\(\sigma = \frac{1}{4} \cdot a \cdot c = \frac{2}{3\cdot5} \frac{\pi^5 k^4}{h^3 c^3}  = 5.6704 \cdot 10^{-8}Wm^{-2}K^{-4}\) (\(c\) = light speed)
\[\begin{split} &
\frac{d}{d\Omega} P_{EM}
\stackrel{oriented}{=}
\frac{d}{d\Omega} w_B =
\frac{\mathscr{L}_B}{c}
\end{split} \tag{20}\]
Blackbody Entropy Density \(s_B = \frac{4}{3} aT^4\)
Blackbody Entropy \(S_B = \frac{4}{3} aVT^3\)
Blackbody Inner Energy \(U_B = aVT^4\)
Blackbody Pressure \(P_B = \frac{1}{3} aT^4 \stackrel{unoriented}{=} \frac{1}{3} w_B\)

title: PHYSECON
text:
Optical Radiation: 
Deviation angle of ray beam after refraction (transmission) and diffraction:
\[\begin{split} &
\varsigma =
\alpha + arcsin \left[ sin(\varpi) \sqrt{\eta^2-sin^2(\alpha)} - cos(\varpi)sin(\alpha) \right] - \varpi =
\alpha + \alpha_2 - \varpi
\end{split} \tag{1}\]
where \(\varpi = \beta + \beta_2 = const.\)
Minimal aberration (minimal projection error):
\(\varsigma = \varsigma_{min} \Longleftrightarrow\)
\[\begin{split} &
\varsigma_{min} \Longleftrightarrow \\
\frac{d}{d\alpha} \varsigma = 0
\ \wedge \\
\varsigma_{min} =
2\alpha - \varpi =
2(\alpha - \beta)
\end{split} \tag{2}\]

title: PHYSECON
text:
Radiation Power and Transfer
Power \(\equiv\) Radiant Flux: 
\[\begin{split} &
\Phi =
\frac{d}{dt}W =
|\frac{1}{\mu_0}(\mathscr{E} \times \mathscr{B} ) | =
| \mathscr{S} | =
\oint\limits_A\, \mathscr{S}\, d\vec{A}
\end{split} \tag{1}\]
\(dW \equiv\) Radiant Energy, \(W \equiv\) Work 
\(\mathscr{S} \equiv\) Poynting-Vector, \(A \equiv\) radiant surface area, \(d\vec{A} \perp dA\) 
Flux Density \(\equiv\) Radiant Intensity (ray beam angular from source at distance \(g\)): 
\(\mathscr{J} = \frac{d\Phi}{d\Omega_g}\)
\(\mathscr{J}_{\lambda} = \frac{c}{\lambda^2} \mathscr{J}_{\nu}\)
\[\begin{split} &
d\mathscr{J} = \frac{d^2\Phi}{d\Omega_g} =
\frac{d^2\Phi}{ \frac{dA_b \cos(\varepsilon_b)}{R^2} } =
\mathscr{L} dA_g \cos(\varepsilon_g)
\end{split} \tag{2}\]
where Radiance \(\mathscr{L}\) = const.
Irradiance \(\equiv\) Impact Intensity (ray beam straight at receiver in distance \(b\)): 
\(\mathscr{I} = \frac{d\Phi}{dA_b} = \mathscr{J} \frac{\cos(\varepsilon_b)}{R^2} = \frac{d\mathscr{H}}{dt}\)
Radiant Exposure \(\equiv\) Action: 
\(\mathscr{H} = \int\limits_{t_1}^{t_2}\, \mathscr{I}(t)\, dt\)
Radiant Exitance \(\equiv\) Radiant Emittance:

\(\mathscr{M} = \frac{d\Phi}{dA_g}\)
Radiance \(\equiv\) Radiant Density (Apparency, Brightness): 
Emissity  \(\equiv \mathscr{L}_g\) 
Appearence Areas: \(dA_g \cos(\varepsilon_g)\) and \(dA_b \cos(\varepsilon_b)\) 
\[\begin{split} &
\mathscr{L} =
\frac{d\mathscr{J}}{dA_g \cdot \cos(\varepsilon_g)} =
\frac{1}{dA_g \cos(\varepsilon_g)} \frac{d^2\Phi}{d\Omega_g} =
\frac{1}{dA_b \cos(\varepsilon_b)} \frac{d^2\Phi}{d\Omega_b} =
\frac{c}{4\pi} w_{EM}
\end{split} \tag{3}\]
\(\mathscr{L} = const.\): diffused emission, reflection, brightness, rough no mirroring surface   …
\(\mathscr{L} \neq\) const.: radiation transfer, no diffusion, apparent, smooth surface mirroring …

title: PHYSECON
text:
Refraction for identifying matter (property of matter):
\[\begin{split} &
\eta
\stackrel{opt.}{=}
\frac{sin(\alpha)}{\sin(\beta)} =
\frac{\eta_{\beta}}{\eta_{\alpha}}
\stackrel{prism}{=}
\frac{ \sin[\frac{1}{2}(\varpi + \varsigma_{min})] }{ \sin[\frac{1}{2}\varpi ] }
\stackrel{phys.}{=}
\sqrt{ \epsilon_r \mu_r } =
\frac{\lambda_{\alpha}}{\lambda_{\beta}} =
\frac{v_{ph,\alpha}}{v_{ph,\beta}} =
\frac{1}{2} \frac{\lambda}{d} \frac{n}{\cos(\beta)} =
\sqrt{\left( \frac{n}{2} \frac{\lambda}{d} \right)^2 + \sin(\alpha)^2}
\stackrel{dispersion}{=}
\eta(\lambda) =
\eta(\omega)
\stackrel{anisotropy}{=}
\eta(r)
\end{split} \tag{1}\]
\[ % \footnote{Brechkraft}
\textnormal{Vacuum } \iff \eta=1
\newline
f = Focal Length        \qquad
D = Refractive Power (Dioptri)
\]
\[
n \equiv \textnormal{order ("Quantum"): } \newline
n =
\frac{\nu}{c} \Delta s =
\frac{\Delta\varphi}{2\pi} =
2 \eta \frac{d}{\lambda} \sqrt{\eta^2 - \sin(\alpha)^2} =
2 \eta \frac{d}{\lambda} \cos(\beta) =
\frac{q}{e_0}
\qquad \in \mathbb{N}
\]
\[
v^2 =
\left( \frac{\nu\lambda}{\eta} \right)^2 =
\left( \frac{\omega}{k \eta} \right)^2
\]
\[
\left( \frac{\eta}{c} \right) ^2 =
\epsilon \mu    \qquad
\epsilon = \epsilon_0 \epsilon_r    \qquad
\mu = \mu_0 \mu_r
\]
where:
\(\alpha \coloneqq\) irradiaton angle, incoming radiation direction, from source/sender (Einstrahlungswinkel zur Normalen auf Grenzfläche des Mediums)
\(\beta \coloneqq\) refraction angle for bented transmitted radiation \(A_{t}\) orientation in matter (Durchstrahlungsswinkel zur Normalen aus Grenzfläche ins Medium)
Orientation of Radiation:



Radiation


\(\vartheta =\) reflection angle for redirected radiation \(A_{r\parallel}\) parallel to \(\alpha\) from matter 
\(\theta =\) diffraction angle for redirected radiation \(A_{r\perp}\) orthogonal to \(\alpha\) from matter 
\(\varpi = \beta_1 + \beta_2 =\) angle of converging body surfaces (point tip of prismic medium), spread angle of prism
\(\varsigma =\) deviation angle of redirected ray beam after refraction (transmission) and diffraction
\(u_g =\) aperture angle (acceptance) from sender source (at distance \(g\))
\(w_b =\) inclination angle at observer receiver (at distance \(b\))
\(\varepsilon =\) visual angle from observer/receiver (of eye)

title: PHYSECON
text:
Sharpness:
\(nN = \frac{\lambda}{\Delta \lambda}, \qquad  N \in \mathbb{N}\)

title: PHYSECON
text:
Wavefunction:
\[\begin{split} &
\Psi(x,t) =
C \cdot e^{ i(\omega t - kx) } =
C \cdot e^{ \frac{i}{\hbar}(Et - pr) }
\stackrel{Wavepacket}{=}
A(x,t) e^{i(\omega_0 t - k_0 x)} =
2 C(k_0) \frac{ sin \left[\left( t \cdot \left( \frac{d\omega}{dk} \right)_{k_0} - x \right) \cdot \Delta k \right] }{ \left( t \cdot \left( \frac{d\omega}{dk} \right)_{k_0} - x \right) } =
2 C(k_0) \frac{ sin \left[\left( \omega't - x \right) \cdot \Delta k \right] }{ \left( \omega't - x \right) } =
2 C(k_0) \Delta k \frac{sin(\xi)}{\xi}
\end{split} \tag{1}\]

title: PHYSECON
text:
\(\exists\) Work done or received \(W \neq 0 \Rrightarrow \exists\) Change of State (“Displacement”, “Deformation”) \(r \neq 0\):
\[\begin{split} &
E = \mathcal{K} + \mathcal{U}  \qquad  E_{kin} \coloneqq \mathcal{K} = \frac{1}{2}pv   \qquad   E_{pot} \coloneqq \mathcal{U} = \mathcal{V} + \mathcal{Z}
\end{split} \tag{1}\]
Energy is conserved in konservative systems; There is no work in closed path between two points (loop) of any shape under path variation, hence the “Principle of Action” applies (extremities of bumps and saddles exist): \(\delta A = 0\)
Potentials: \[\begin{split} &
\mathcal{U} = \mathcal{V} + \mathcal{Z}
\\&
\mathcal{V}
    \begin{cases}
      = \frac{1}{2} kr^2 : \text{isotrop harmonical oscilator central field Potential, } \\
        \qquad \text{closed bounded path, } \text{"spring constant" } k = m\omega^2 = 2\pi \cdot \nu  \\
      = -\frac{1}{r}\alpha: \text{gravitational central field Potential, } \\
        \qquad \text{closed bounded path, } \alpha = \left( \frac{2\pi}{\Delta \varphi} \right)^2 = const. \\
      \sim \frac{1}{r}e^{\mu r} : \text{Yukawa Potential}, \text{"Photon mass" } m_{\gamma} = \mu \frac{\hbar}{c} \\
      ...
    \end{cases}
\end{split} \tag{2}\]
Centrifugal Potential: \[\begin{split} &
\mathcal{Z} = \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{m} \left( \frac{L_0}{r} \right)^2 \text{, angular momentum}=L_0
\end{split} \tag{3}\]
Work: \[\begin{split} &
W = \partial_t A = \partial_t (E \cdot t) = \partial_t (p ⋅ r) = F_1 \cdot r_1 + p_2 \cdot v_2 =
    \begin{cases}
      F \cdot r \\
      p \cdot v
    \end{cases}
\end{split} \tag{4}\]
Geometrical:
\[\begin{split} &
W = F \cdot r = mr \cdot a = I ⋅ \frac{v}{t} =  \frac{p}{t} ⋅ tv = Ft \cdot v =  pv = mv^2
\end{split} \tag{5}\]
Analytical:
\[\begin{split} &
\mathcal{L} = \mathcal{L}(r,\dot r,t) = E_{kin} - E_{pot}
\end{split} \tag{6}\]
\[\begin{split} &
\mathcal{H} = \mathcal{H}(r,p,t) = \sum_i^f \dot r_i p_i - \mathcal{L}
\stackrel{konserv.}{=}
E_{kin} + E_{pot} = const.
\end{split} \tag{7}\]
\[\begin{split} &
A = E \cdot t = p \cdot r
\stackrel{\mathcal{H}=0}{=}
\int_{t_0}^{t_x} \mathcal{L} dt
\end{split} \tag{8}\]
\[\begin{split} &
W = p \cdot v = \mathcal{L} + \mathcal{H} = (\mathcal{K} - \mathcal{U}) + \mathcal{H}
\\& \stackrel{konserv.}{=}
(\mathcal{K} - \mathcal{U}) + (\mathcal{K} + \mathcal{U}) = (\mathcal{K} - \mathcal{U}) + E
\end{split} \tag{9}\]
Electro Magnetic:
\[\begin{split} &
W = \mathcal{L} + \mathcal{H} = \left( \frac{1}{2}mv^2 - q(\Phi - \vec{\mathcal{A}} \cdot \vec{v}) \right) + \left( \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{m} (\vec{p} - q\vec{\mathcal{A}})^2 + q\Phi \right)\end{split} \tag{10}\]
Relativistic:
\[\begin{split} &
W = p \cdot v = \frac{v}{c} \sqrt{E^2 - (mc^2)^2}
\end{split} \tag{11}\]
Thermal:
\[\begin{split} &
W = Fr = PV^{\iota} = T \cdot V^{\frac{f+2}{f}} = T \cdot V^{(\frac{c_P}{c_V}-1)} = TV^{\kappa-1}  \\&
= T \cdot l \cdot g_0 = T \cdot n \cdot b_0 = T \cdot m \cdot c_0
\end{split} \tag{12}\]
Thermo Statistical:
\[\begin{split} &
W = \mathcal{L} + \mathcal{H} = ΔU - ΔH = \Delta(T \cdot \Delta S - P \cdot \Delta V) - \Delta(T\cdot S)
\end{split} \tag{13}\]
Quantistic:
\[\begin{split} &
W = p \cdot v = ħ\mathcal{k} \cdot ω = ℎν\mathcal{k} = E\mathcal{k}
\end{split} \tag{14}\]
\[\begin{split} &
\Delta A = \Delta p  \cdot \Delta r = \Delta E \cdot \Delta t \ge \frac{1}{2} \hbar
\end{split} \tag{15}\]
